chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess someone with suspected uveitis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Take a medical history, and ask: 
    • About the signs and symptoms, including the onset and duration. 
    • If symptoms are unilateral or bilateral.
    • If vision is affected, or there is an increase in floaters. 
    • If there is any pain – the type of pain (for example, dull, or throbbing), the intensity, and the location (ophthalmic, or non-ophthalmic eye pain).
    • About a foreign body sensation – this suggests a corneal process, such as corneal abrasion, retained foreign body, or keratitis.
    • If eyes are watering more than normal, or if there is any discharge (discharge is notably absent in uveitis). 
    • If there is photophobia. 
    • Previous illnesses, including previous eye problems.
    • Medication – drug-induced uveitis is rare and usually begins days to months after exposure. 
    • Whether the person wears contact lenses — if they do, ask about the hygiene routine. Keratitis is associated with inappropriate contact lens use and care. 
    • If there is any history of chemical exposure, trauma or surgery. 
    • Family history — autoimmune disorders have a genetic predisposition and are seen more commonly in family members. 
  • Conduct a physical examination: 
    • If perforation of the globe is suspected (for instance in ocular trauma or as a complication of scleritis), do not palpate the eye — arrange for urgent ophthalmology assessment.
    • Assess for evidence of facial trauma.
    • Examine the eyelids for inflammation and erythema, or any abnormalities (for example, trichiasis, entropion or ectropion). 
      • Also examine the eyelids and surrounding area for rashes and vesicles.  
    • Examine the conjunctiva, including the tarsal surface. 
      • If foreign body is a possibility, invert the upper lid to check for a sub-tarsal foreign body. 
    • Check the pattern of redness (if present) — ciliary flush, where the limbal vessels (where the cornea meets the sclera) are injected, is seen in more serious causes of red eye, such as anterior uveitis and corneal causes. 
    • Perform fluorescein examination — if the cornea stains this can be an indication that a corneal abrasion or ulcer is present.
    • Check for any discharge from the eye(s).
    • Check the person's visual acuity using a Snellen chart. 
    • Check extraocular movement. 
    • Check pupil reactions, using a pen torch (or equivalent).
      • Check if the person is photophobic.
      • Observe pupil size and shape — the pupil may be smaller than on the unaffected side as inflammation may trigger muscle spasm of the iris sphincter, or distorted by posterior synechiae.
      • Check direct and consensual pupillary reflexes.
    • Check intraocular pressure (depending on local resources).
    • Check the person's blood pressure.
  • Clinical features of uveitis vary depending on the location of the inflammation and are usually unilateral (if bilateral it is more likely to be associated with systemic disease and likely to become chronic). They include:
    • Pain or dull ache (pain may be worse when the person is contracting the ciliary muscle — for example, when reading). 
      • Pain may extend from the eye to the surrounding orbit and may be tender to palpation through the eyelid. 
      • Posterior uveitis may be painless. 
    • Red eye (this is not always present).
    • Diminished or blurred vision (although vision may be normal but become impaired later). 
    • Watering of the eye. 
    • Photophobia. 
    • Flashes and floaters. 
    • An unreactive or distorted pupil (due to the iris sticking to the lens). 
  • Symptoms may develop over hours or days (acute uveitis), or onset may be gradual (chronic uveitis). 
    • If the person has had uveitis before, they may feel the symptoms coming on before the signs are present. 
  • People with chronic uveitis may be completely free of symptoms or experience less severe symptoms: 
    • Recurrent uveitis may be asymptomatic, and the eye may be white despite the presence of inflammation. 
  • Be aware that uveitis is more likely if the person has a condition that may cause uveitis, or a predisposing risk factor for uveitis, and other eye conditions have been excluded.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the British Medical Journal (BMJ) Best Practice guides Uveitis [BMJ, 2018] and Assessment of red eye [BMJ Best Practice, 2018], the College of Optometrists guideline Uveitis (anterior), expert opinion in narrative reviews Investigation and management of uveitis [Guly, 2010], Evaluation of the painful eye [Pflipsen, 2016], Assessing the painful, uninflamed eye in primary care [Kuffova, 2015], Chronic non-infectious uveitis in the elderly: epidemiology, pathophysiology and management [Gupta, 2006], Uveitis: the collaborative diagnostic evaluation [Harman, 2014], Diagnosis and treatment of anterior uveitis: optometric management [Harthan, 2016], Approach to red eye for primary care practitioners [Dunlop, 2015], The pediatric red eye [Wong, 2014], and a medical textbook Ophthalmology [Yanoff, 2013].
